message:
Hi Geeks, i want to ask u about something but i don't know if it is violates the posting roles; if it is , feel free to remove it ;)

I was asked to develop an app for a clinic, obviously this is supposed to be a small project. I am a web developer but due to the project size i considered Java Swing, as it is easy to install and doesn't require an application server to run it. 

due to your experience, is this a good decision. java swing with old JDBC is fine with small apps ?

data.message: why not? If you can be productive with it quickly, then it is a good choice. Old JDBC or ODBC is fine as you just need to connect to the database and do your usual CRUD operations.
because i would need another apps to make it running. like a web server . I am just aiming for simplicity and speed development. I am afraid that the client will feel strange to use IE or FireFox

why not as M.Samy said ... even if it's not the best way to develop on windows ... always consider the time constraints ... for sure, you will take a lot of time to learn something new ... this learning curve time will be added to the total project time... Thus if you are learning something complex you will take a lot of time which will make the project revenue like nothing for you.. the more simple, fast the better it is for business apps if you are seeking revenue ... otherwise, if you are seeking to get some knowledge and invest in yourself ... I think using the WPF framework would be a very good fancy choice for doing such a windows application like this 1.... best wishes;

Well, it is all up to you .. What I suggest is (it might be wrong):
since you are a web developer, you can use different web technologies to accomplish the assigned project .. afterwards you can either submit a documentation for the people who are going to use that app for the clients so that they get to know how to use it or you simply educate them of how to use the app.

Web server might be a problem if you are working with web technologies .. Okay, forget about my suggestion for now and go for the most productive way you are familiar with

(I should be in bed by now) =D
Why you wanna go for Java instead of going for a lighter framework? Something like Sinatra, Ruby can help you get the job done very fast and easily!

I used Nullsoft installer to create a setup file that gives the client this "offline application feel". The installer installs the HTTP server, the database server and configures everything and then adds a shortcut to the application on the user desktop. Unless the user is very perceptive and tech-savvy, he may not notice he is running a web app

http://nsis.sourceforge.net/Main_Page

Mohamed Alaa El Din that's off topic from what the OP was asking for. The OP is talking swing, so it's clearly a desktop application, Sinatra won't build you a desktop app.

One possible option, is to build a desktop application using web technologies, the sdk I tried for this was http://www.tidesdk.org/

Those were the things i hoped to find.  Thx geks.  U helped a lot .  Last question.  How much money should i ask for?  It ls a tiny app after all.  But i dont have a good knowledge in pricing freelance tasks
